definition: to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-

sentences.english: From award winning Hong Kong directors Alan Mak and Andrew Lau.
sentences.chinese: 出自于得过奖的香港导演麦兆辉与刘伟强。

sentences.english: Have you ever won a prize before?
I see lots of names of people who have won that I’ve never heard of.
sentences.chinese: 我倒是对不少得过奖的人的名字一无所知。

sentences.english: At first, they just took a small amount to buy lottery tickets, but they never won any money.
sentences.chinese: 起初他们只是偷点儿小钱买彩票，但从来没中过奖。

sentences.english: Have you ever won a prize in a competition?
But even "very occasional" was too much for me.
sentences.chinese: 但是“极其偶然”也是过奖了。

sentences.english: All anybody needs to know about prizes is that Mozart never won one.
sentences.chinese: 对于得奖这件事，只要知道莫札特从未得过奖就够了。

sentences.english: He is champion at gym, he has got his football honor.
sentences.chinese: 他可是体操冠军，在足球上也获过奖呢。

definition: lit. I dare not (accept the honor); fig. I don't deserve your praise/you flatter me
to praise too much/I really don't deserve so much praise
to mock/to be ridiculed/to incur ridicule through one's poor performance (humble)
lit. I'm ashamed and dare not (accept the honor); fig. I do not deserve your praise./You flatter me too much.
you let me win (said politely after winning a game)
to overpraise/You praise me too much!
honorific: I've long looked forward to meeting you./It's an honor to meet you at last.
